thread.title: Regional doctors celebrate life outside the profession in photographic exhibition - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Regional doctors celebrate life outside the profession in photographic exhibition - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Abc Far North
title: Regional doctors celebrate life outside the profession in photographic exhibition - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
By Mark Rigby and Kier Shorey Updated February 03, 2017 13:36:53 Map: Cairns 4870 
A photographic exhibition featuring doctors and medical professionals from regional Queensland is giving audiences a look at the faces behind the surgical masks. 
The candid exhibition features more than 80 doctors doing the things they love when they are away from work. 
Photographers Danielle Hodgens, George Kneipp, Joseph Jacobs and Dr Tim Carruthers worked collaboratively for 12 months to bring the exhibition to life. 
"We all formed a team, and every month the team would meet to decide who would photograph which doctors," Ms Hodgens said. 
"Every single weekend, for 12 months, we were photographing." 
Initially the doctors featured in the exhibition were going to don uniforms and instruments synonymous with their profession. Photo: Dr Natalie Kiesey-Calding has passed her love of fashion on to her two daughters. (Supplied: Dr Tim Warnock ) 
But early in the development of the project it became clear that idea was not going to work. 
"Most of them were going to wear a stethoscope or wear their surgical scrubs and they would have all looked the same," Ms Hodgens said. 
"That idea was dropped and we photographed the doctors in their usual attire, whether it was baggy old jeans or whatever." Photo: A lack of luthiers in regional Queensland led Dr Peter Hammer to teach himself to make simple adjustments and repairs. (Supplied: Joseph Jacobs) 
Ms Hodgens said the process of putting the exhibition together had taught her a great deal about regional Queensland's medical professionals. 
"I spoke with at least 45 of the doctors â€¦ and the huge contributions they make to the community are quite often not recognised," she said. 
"I know they would be thanked, but very often they're not thanked to the extent they should be." Photo: The A Street Band is comprised entirely of medical health professionals from Atherton, south-west of Cairns, far north Queensland. (Supplied: Danielle Hodgens/George/Kneipp) 
The ultimate aim of the exhibition, which Ms Hodgens describes as "a huge art project", is to unmask medical professionals and show them doing the things they love to do with their spare time. 
"The public can see that doctors and medical specialists who sometimes work 16 hours a day are human beings as well," Ms Hodgens said.
